misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No bug / correct parallel-array sort mental model
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that to sort parallel arrays by score, you must swap both the score and the corresponding name whenever two adjacent scores are out of order, and then the highest score will end up at the last index.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: No conceptual gap detected here: this matches Java’s actual execution model. The nested loops implement bubble sort in ascending order, and swapping both arrays preserves the name-score pairing. After sorting ascending, accessing index N-1 correctly retrieves the maximum score and its associated name.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None (produces correct output for the stated requirements, assuming valid inputs and N > 0).

evidence.code_snippet:
String topName = names[N - 1];
	int topScore = scores_array[N - 1];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes there will always be at least one student (N > 0), so it’s safe to access index N-1 after reading input.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays have valid indices 0..N-1 only when N>=1. If N==0, any access to names[N-1] or scores_array[N-1] attempts index -1 and crashes. This is a mismatch between assumed input constraints and actual runtime behavior when constraints aren’t enforced in code.
